item.description:
Sinners came home today.

I attended a special community screening in Clarksdale, MS

I was in the same room as Ryan Coogler, Miles Caton, and Ludwig Göransson. The audience was a blast, and the big finale got so much applause I felt catharsis. Literally no other audience has applauded MBJ obliterating the Klan until this one, and they LOVED it

item.title: The Brutalist, 2024 - ★★★★
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
OVERTURE

Chains and screams and joy and hugs as the Statue of Liberty enters the frame unexpectedly from the top, staring down at us like a giant mother.

THE ENIGMA OF ARRIVAL

Attila welcomes his cousin with tears and introduces him to his quarters as a servant, mentioning only the employee restroom. Attila's insecurity drives László out. The weakness of the man and the woman's suggestion create a reality that is actively hostile toward László.

And this is how America seems to be designed: to separate, to subjugate, and to sell.

Bicycle. Tricycle. Family.

The act of immigration is an act of faith that life can be made, that we can choose better things for ourselves and give more to our friends and family. The promise of America is that all of this is possible.

That promise will seem like a lie by the end of this film, but the hope in this story is not rooted in the American dream.

"Is there a better description of a cube than that of its construction?"

Doylestown represents small-town America, contrasting the NYC arrival with a rural community. The project is only welcomed by the community once it is demonstrated to be sufficiently Christian—a thread that is important in history because of the bloodshed it has caused.

INTERMISSION

I am pleased that the intermission exists in streaming, even if only for a minute. I did enjoy the music during the theatrical intermission.

THE HARD CORE OF BEAUTY

Only Maggie cares enough to show up with László to greet Zsófia and Erzsébet. I think this film shows women honestly, and we are meant to draw conclusions from how loud the men end up being. Perhaps my main criticism of this film is that we spend so much time with these men when I prefer the women, yet it reflects reality to spend more time listening to flawed men.

Beauty's core is hard because it comes from truth.

EPILOGUE

Truth told through storytelling is an expression of the storyteller.

The storyteller all along is Zsófia, and she succumbs to the same ill fate as her uncle László and survives her aunt Erzsébet to speak for him as the concluding point of this film. Harry rapes Zsófia, but it happens off-screen. Harrison rapes László.

The Brutalist depicts this American story in America, but the rape depicted on screen happens in Italy. What are we to make of the rape that we know happened off-screen, in America—in our own Pennsylvania?

item.title: Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker, 2019 - ★★½
item.ns0:filmTitle: Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
this whole film feels like overcompensation for the rest of the sequel trilogy. it tries to do way too much without really knowing what purpose it has in doing it.

this entry doesn't fail because of nostalgia bait. it fails because it should have been the story of the sequel trilogy from the beginning, and it was not.

item.title: Star Wars: The Last Jedi, 2017 - ★★★½
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description: gonna go ahead and keep this at 3.5 stars because it's clearly the best of the sequel trilogy but it is still constrained by a formula, if only active rebellion of the formula.

item.title: Star Wars: The Force Awakens, 2015 - ★★★
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
i like plenty of this to remember why i gave it 3 stars.

i actively dislike enough of this to remember why i left two stars off.

the nostalgia bait has not aged well.

item.title: Solo: A Star Wars Story, 2018 - ★★★½
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
i haven't logged this since i watched it in theaters which was before i joined the letterboxd

it's mostly action set-pieces and lore, and tbh i think it's actually quite high quality. especially with the likes of woody harrelson and thandie newton. alden is great (omg is he great) and emilia was in everything else at the time, so why not a star war too? emilia i could live without, but her setup of the only cameo was WORTH

i'd be down for more movies with Alden and Donald hanging out and doing some casual crimes

item.title: JXNFC - Animated Features
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
• The Land Before Time

    Entered by Michael

    This film is my waypoint for consciousness -- I came to and understanding of death emotionally because of this movie. Nothing has ever quite hit the same, to be honest.

  • Rock-A-Doodle

    Entered by Michael

    When my parents would go to their weekly bowling league, I was the kid who would change the TV to Rock-A-Doodle at the childcare center next door.

  • One Hundred and One Dalmatians

    Entered by Michael

  • Princess Mononoke

    Entered by Michael

    This was when I realized that animation is for grownups, and that grownup stories can be told through animation. I love how this changed my imagination.

  • Spirited Away

    Entered by Michael

    I found this not far from the age of Chihiro. It means a lot to me because I moved twice before the age of 10 and this film teaches about life in its own way, through the eyes of a young person who has been Spirited Away.

  • Samurai Champloo

    Entered by Michael

    This anime popped up on Adult Swim, but I never finished the series on the air. Nearly 20 years later, I've finally watched the entirety and absolutely loved the ending.

  • The Hobbit

    Entered by Morgan

  • Heavy Metal

    Entered by Morgan

  • Waking Life

    Entered by Morgan

  • The Secret of Kells

    Entered by Morgan

...plus 1 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: JXNFC: Quentin's Top 20
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
Quentin Jones, friend of the film club, listed his top 20 on the most recent episode of Jackson Film Club The Podcast.

Quentin found himself in Jackson after working on the film crew for the episode of We Are Here created in Jackson in 2022. His first and foremost reason for his residence in the city is the love of his life, Lydia. His second reason is his mission for cannabis awareness and advancement in the state's new medical marijuana program. His third reason is the great dance floor at Shade.

This top 20 list features epic American classics and some of the most innovative and groundbreaking cinema in the world. Tune in to our conversation wherever you get your podcasts.

Though this is presented as a ranked list, the films in positions 22 - 24 are honorable mentions and despicable artists-now-canceled.

  1. Get Out
  2. The Big Lebowski
  3. In the Mood for Love
  4. Hairspray
  5. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
  6. Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse
  7. Blue Velvet
  8. Do the Right Thing
  9. Moonlight
  10. Barbie

...plus 14 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: 2022 Goal: 100 New Directors
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
I started the year with a pretty interesting ratio of 1.28:1 for number of films by a director. On 14 October 2021 I reached a milestone of 500 directors from 646 logged films, spanning 41 countries, inspiring my 2022 goal of watching 100 movies introducing myself to that many more new directors. As of completion of this goal, my ratio is 1.33 movies per director with over 700 directors logged. I look forward to seeing where it's at when I hit 1500 movies logged

tl;dr: for every movie on this list, 2022 is the first time I’ve seen something from that director.

  1. The Hand of God
  2. The Lost Daughter
  3. Summer of Soul (...Or, When the Revolution Could Not Be Televised)
  4. The Mask of Zorro
  5. The Paradise Next Door
  6. Lunch on the Grass
  7. Doctor Strange
  8. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
  9. A Bridge Too Far
  10. Encanto

...plus 89 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: JXNFC Topic: Soundtracks

item.title: JXNFC: Jonathan’s Top 20 Films
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
Classics, action, comedy, fantasy. This list has a little of everything.

  1. The Big Lebowski

    The greatest film ever made, bar none. Shut the fuck up, Donny

  2. The Nice Guys

    Just two guys, in way over their heads.

  3. There Will Be Blood

    One of the greatest Method acting performances of all time, although my contention will ever be that Daniel Day-Lewis deserved his second Oscar before this for Gangs of New York.

  4. Hell or High Water

    The best Texas noir film since No Country For Old Men.

  5. Pride & Prejudice

    A stirringly scored, beautifully shot adaptation of the Austen novel.

  6. The Searchers

    A visually brilliant, brutally spectacular film, and the performance that should have won John Wayne his Academy Award, for bitter, racist ex-Confederate Ethan Edwards.

  7. Zodiac

    David Fincher’s masterpiece. A stacked cast and a case that was never solved.

  8. When Harry Met Sally...

    The ultimate rom-com

  9. Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby

    If you eat the DVD, it tastes like America

  10. Silver Linings Playbook

    Go Birds

...plus 10 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.

item.title: JXNFC: Jake’s Top 20
item.dc:creator: Michael Lamb
item.description:
• Cool Hand Luke

    A crash course in humanity. 

    "No man can eat 50 eggs."

  • The Godfather

    A crash course in film. Perfect in every aspect.

  • Blood Simple

    #3 is a revolving door of Coen films. This spot belongs to whichever I'm feeling the most on a given day. Their debut is underappreciated and seems like an appropriate placeholder.

  • Butch Cassidy and the Sundance Kid

    Every top 20 should have a western. And the best westerns are about bucking authority and beating the odds.

  • The Truman Show

    My life is definitely not filled by paid actors. But my brain thinks it might be.

  • Big Night

    The movie that taught me to appreciate food. And business. And Louie Prima.

    "Bite your teeth into the ass of life."

  • White Men Can't Jump

    Iconic 90s.

  • Thicker Than Water

    When I am wistful, surf docs settle my soul. This one is my go to.

  • Good Will Hunting

    Robin Williams at his very best and most vulnerable. RIP.

  • Attack the Block

    Pure fun. Easily my favorite monster movie.

...plus 10 more. View the full list on Letterboxd.
